title: Ticket #4338: Investigate reporting memory usage of VMs
description: I closed ticket #4337 after getting only the CPU usage reporting working. TimC is interested in memory reporting, especially in terms of determining if assuming that RequestMemory = vm_memory is the correct default. (For instance, will assuming that there's no overhead cause heaving paging when the sum of vm_memory is equal to the system's physical RAM?) For KVM only. If the information returned by libvirt's virDomainGetInfo() -- "the memory in KBytes used by the domain" -- is the right thing, this shouldn't take too long to do.
remarks:
2014-Dec-16 15:18:51 by tlmiller:
Broken in testing on CHTC. Sometimes a VMU job will report correctly: 

006 (171360.000.000) 12/16 13:25:37 Image size of job updated: 2097152
	2097152  -  ResidentSetSize of job (KB)
...

sometimes it will get 

006 (171404.000.000) 12/16 13:28:47 Image size of job updated: 8029125568646952238
	959329332  -  ResidentSetSize of job (KB)
...

which is wrong in at least two ways.

I see two things worth investigating: the conversion from unsigned long to long long when adding the memory value to the string before sending it to the starter, and the starter converting that value into a signed long int, instead. Second, the data structure in question is never zeroed; perhaps in certain cases the memory usage field is never filled out and we're picking arbitrary garbage off the stack?

2015-Jan-05 16:21:19 by tlmiller:
Was only able to reproduce once; analysis indicated the problem was probably occurring in shadow or the schedd, and may be the result of a race condition (although that doesn't make a whole lot of sense, since neither of those have VMU-specific code; maybe the unmasking factor is that the VMU doesn't send a memory size update until well after the initial execution report?).

2015-Feb-17 14:05:56 by tlmiller:

2015-Feb-17 14:25:43 by tlmiller:
Move documentation to subticket, since we haven't told anyone about this yet.
